title: trevor kavanagh no deal full british brexit leave
story: Asked by a major pro-Brexit industrialist how Brussels might respond, I am told a rattled German official replied: “We would re-open negotiations immediately.”Yesterday, Jeremy Hunt broke cover as the first senior minister to publicly back a Full British Brexit — precisely what .million voters ordered more than two years ago.“I’ve always thought even in a No-Deal situation that this is a great country,” he said. “We’ll find a way to flourish and prosper. We’ve faced much bigger challenges in our history.”It was a shrewd move by the ambitious Foreign Secretary.  Leaving the EU without a deal has suddenly become a hot favourite with Brexit leadership rivals. It is also the outcome feared most in the capitals of Europe.The German official’s response is shocking proof that Theresa May’s mantra: “No Deal is better than a Bad Deal” was always seen as an empty bluff.It also refutes the claim that her widely-loathed withdrawal plan is the only option available from Brussels. Mr Hunt brushed aside Project Fear’s portrayal of a “Car Crash” Brexit and insisted Britain can cope with all challenges.“We shouldn’t pretend there won’t be disruption,” he admitted. “That’s why as a responsible government we have to make all the preparations necessary.”Far from the clf-edge, car-crash nightmare painted by the Treasury, BBC and CBI, a clean Brexit is entirely manageable. It would set us free to trade on terms set by the Government in the interests of the British people.We would save the £billion ransom to Brussels — and use some of the cash to buy time from the EU for more detailed planning. And it would see off slippery Tony Blair’s treacherous call for a second referendum.Yes, there would be turbulence as the UK adjusted to ending  years of EU membership.  But experts such as ex-Bank of England governor Mervyn King predict we will look back on this moment and barely see a blip on our economic growth chart.Indeed, economists believe Britain will thrive and prosper once free from EU shackles. So why are Remainer MPs so implacably determined to stop it  Why are they reneging on their own manesto pledges and threatening to overturn the legislation which set the March deadline Simple. Once we are out, we are out for ever. We can prove we are a great world economy, trading to every corner of the globe — Europe included. We would never rejoin the cosy exclusive club beloved of the political elite, unelected bigwigs and business fat cats who ride the Brussels gravy train.Only  per cent of UK goods — one eighth — goes to Europe, with the rest heading for the wider world or home markets.The EU share of world trade is on the slide. Game-changing technology is alien to its socialist outlook. Where, for instance, is the EU equivalent of Apple, Microsoft, Amazon or Google Brussels turns its face against progress — allegedly because it threatens jobs. Yet Eurozone unemployment is double Britain’s and criminally high among young people.Remainers claim under-s are fans of the EU and would vote Remain in a second referendum. Labour is trying to cash in by cutting the voting age from  to . Yet a revealing new poll suggests the youth of Britain and Europe sees right through the EU drive for a political and economic superstate.Given the choice, they pick free markets, low tax and low regulation over the suffocatingly interventionist Grand Project. These tech-savvy youngsters can see Europe is trailing behind while unimaginable opportunities from robot technology and Articial Intelligence unfold.Britain would miss out too, barred by EU regulation,we tied ourselves indefinitely to this inward-looking protectionist bloc. A Full Brexit might cause a few short- term hiccups for just-in-time deliveries, but they will be quickly forgotten as decades of opportunity are opened up by Brexit.UKplc has nothing to fear but Project Fear itself. Warnings of economic chaos, mass unemployment and house price crashes have repeatedly proved to be .The same scare stories were peddled by the same people who  years ago predicted Britain would sink unless we joined the European single currency. We never looked back. It is the Eurozone that is now sinking, with Greece already under water. Britain’s jobs miracle is the envy of EuropeThe Eurozone is mired in a crisis inflicted by uncontrolled mass immigration and youth alienation.  The most patriotic Frenchman couldn’t claim Paris is nice at this time of the year. By contrast Britain is a hive of activity, with steady growth, booming exports and a jobs miracle which is the envy of Europe.The UK is a magnet to the EU’s unemployed and to foreign investment worth billions from tech giants such as Apple, Amazon and Google — despite Brexit.Leaving without a deal on March  is our best chance of implementing the  referendum and escaping from a teetering, corrupt and arrogant political fantasy before it implodes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl letter father christmas perfect handwriting
story: The faded letter, hidden in a book donated to an Oxfam store, is a heart-warming insight into what presents kids wanted at the time.Marjorie, the well-off daughter of a cotton trader, marked out lines with her pencil and wrote in near-perfect joined-up handwriting, addressing it simply to ‘Father Christmas, North Pole’.She writes: “Dear Father Christmas. When you come to see us on Christmas Eve will you please bring us some little toy ducks and chickens for a present, also a canvas stocking like you bought us last year.“You will see an extra stocking hanging up this time, it is for Kittikins she would like a piece of ribbon and a ball in hers. With love and kisses from us both. Your loving Marjorie.”The letter was discovered carefully placed inside an old book that was donated to a branch of Oxfam in Deal, Kent.Lily Birchall, , who now works for Whirligig Toys in nearby Canterbury, was handed the ageing letter by her father Matthew, , who used to work in the charity shop.When she saw it she thought it was so lovely she decided to base the toy store’s annual Christmas window display on it.Lily, from Deal, said: “When I saw the letter I thought it was really, really special.“It’s just the mystery of it - who was this little girl and what happened to her  The writing and the message are beautul.Fellow staff member Gemma Gale, , added: “You couldn’t fail to be moved by it.“It’s such a sweet, innocent letter. People have been visiting the window just to see it.”Marjorie - whose middle name was Wilhemina - was born in October  at Hindley Lodge in Hindley, near Wigan, Lancs.But the family relocated south when her father, the cotton manufacturer and mill owner William T Pennington, died just days after her birth aged only .By the time of the  census, the little girl and her mother Annie, , brother Richard, nine, grandmother Amelia Watson, , and governess Mary Edmunds, , had moved to  Enys Road, Eastbourne.At the time, the property, in a well-to-do area of the East Sussex seaside town, was known as Bellavista and it was there that Marjorie wrote and posted her Christmas note.The house was destroyed by a direct hit from a Nazi bomb on October ,  - the th to hit the area - and was replaced by flats.Alan Smith, of Eastbourne Local History Society, is now planning on researching Marjorie’s le in the town.He said: “Enys Road was an upper middle class area. A lot of children around there would have been sent back from the colonies for schooling.“Letters like that are rare. It’s lovely to see.”The window display featuring the letter has now won first prize in the annual Canterbury’s Best Dressed Christmas Window competition.Whirligig’s founder, Peter Allinson, said there wasn’t a single person who had seen the letter who wasn’t moved by its simplicity.According to Findmypast, which carried out the research into Marjorie, the little girl became a solicitor, ed to her native Wigan and became a solicitor, dying in .Researcher Alex Cox said: “It’s a truly wonderful letter and there are literally millions of stories just like Marjorie’s that have been lost to history and are still waiting to be told.”

title: theresa may tony blair damaging second brexit referendum
story: As she tries to unite her party in opposition to the former PM, she will plead with them not to back another vote on Brexit.Ex-PM Mr Blair has been begging for another vote for months, saying its the only way to figure out what the people really want.Over the weekend he urged Mrs May to ignore the million people who opted for Brexit the first time, and told campaigners to be ready for a second vote within weeks.But a ferocious Mrs May will tell MPs today that it would further ide our country at the very moment we should be working to unite it.“Let us not break faith with the British people by trying to stage another referendum, Mrs May will urge her colleagues.Another vote which would do irreparable damage to the integrity of our politics, because it would say to millions who trusted in democracy, that our democracy does not deliver.And it would likely leave us no further forward than the last, she will say.Yesterday Mrs May launched a blistering attack on the Brexit saboteur, accusing him of insulting the people.And she bluntly reminded him it was his own open-door immigration policy which spurred millions to vote leave.She raged: “There are too many people who want to subvert the process for their own political interests – rather than acting in the national interest.For Tony Blair to go to Brussels and seek to undermine our negotiations by advocating for a second referendum is an insult to the office he once held and the British people he once served.We cannot, as he would, abdicate responsibility for this decision. Parliament has a democratic duty to deliver what the British people voted for.Mrs May’s patience snapped after an exhausting week of clashes with MPs and Eurocrats blocking her departure deal.Mr Blair hit back by saying that Mrs Mays stance was irresponsible.He wants to ask for an extension of Article  to have the time for another vote, or re-open talks with the EU.But the bloc has said time and time again that more talks are NOT an option.It was his decision to unleash a vast, uncontrolled influx of migrants on a country ill-equipped for it... all, as his adviser later admitted, to “rub the Right’s nose in ersity”.It was his lust for wealth after leaving office that saw him torch what was left of his reputation and line his pockets with dictators’ millions.Now Blair is hell-bent on setting a match to our democracy itself as he heads the campaign to reverse the biggest mandate in its history, sabotaging our Brexit negotiating position in the process.And so the trail of destruction he has left for  years goes on. The common thread being his unassailable conviction, despite every single catastrophic mistake, that Tony always knows best.Many of us stopped listening long ago. Time the rest woke up.

title: blurs damon albarn demands citizens
story: NewsBlurs Damon Albarn demands citizens assembly to fix BrexitHes clearly decided Theres No Other Way to break the Brexit deadlockShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe Britpop legend backed a citizens assembly to break the deadlock over leaving the EU "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBlur frontman Damon Albarn has swung behind a new campaign to fix Brexit. The Britpop legend and Gorillaz star today backed a citizens assembly to break the deadlock over leaving the EU. The idea would see a randomly chosen group of  members of the public recommend to MPs what they should do next. Its claimed such a mini-parliament could be organised in eight weeks to start the process of listening to the public. The idea is backed in a letter also signed by former Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams and prizewinning authors Ian McEwan and Jonathan Coe. Together they wrote to : Anger and resentment are growing, splitting families, communities and our country.  Without a new intervention, the toxic culture which has infected public le will irrevocably damage democracy and the future for us all. Albarn shot to fame with Blur in the early s before fronting animated band Gorillaz and launching solo projects. Blur is on long-term hiatus. The singer said last month Brexit doesn’t make any sense to me whatsoever. He told an interviewer: Brexit has revealed terrible truths about the mental health of the English. Something that was so painful for so many years was eventually resolved, and now we’re going back. Todays letter is also backed by the campaign group Unlock Democracy, Dr Jess Garland of the Electoral Reform Society, Neal Lawson of the think tank Compass and Labour peer Ruth Lister. They wrote: Citizens’ assemblies operate around the world to create a neutral forum for evidence-based, participative decision-making. In recent years, they have been used in Ireland, British Columbia and Iceland, and in national and local government in the UK, as democratic “circuit-breakers” on contentious and complex issues.Taking eight weeks to organise, such assemblies are constructed of a randomly chosen representative group of up to  members of the public.They hear a broad range of evidence and arguments on a subject, which they discuss and weigh up before making considered recommendations to their political representatives. It comes as the nation, MPs and the Tory Cabinet remain deadlocked about where to go next with Brexit.  Theresa May has almost hope of getting the UKs Brexit deal through Parliament, and a bid to improve it with the EU ended in disaster last week. Now a string of top ministers have publicly called on the PM to let MPs take control of Brexit by voting on what happens next. Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said: Nothing should be off the table, we should consider all options. Business Secretary Greg Clark said: I think Parliament should be invited to say what it would agree with. But Theresa May will issue a furious riposte to calls for a second EU referendum in an address to Parliament. She will claim a Peoples Vote would break faith with the British people and do irreparable damage to democracy.

title: brexit news peoples vote would
story: NewsTheresa May makes desperate plea against second Brexit referendum as pressure mounts in CabinetThe PM will say a second EU referendum would "break faith with the British people". But shes been forced into it by her own Cabinet - with ministers publicly demanding MPs vote on what happens nextShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorShaun Connolly:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe Prime Minister will tell Parliament a second EU referendum would break faith with the British people "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May will today make a desperate plea against a second Brexit referendum as calls mount for her to offer the nation a new way out. She will claim a Peoples Vote would break faith with the British people and do irreparable damage to democracy in an address to Parliament. Yet the Prime Minister has been forced into this unprecedented attack - after facing pressure from within her own Cabinet. She has almost hope of getting the UKs Brexit deal through Parliament, and a bid to improve it with the EU ended in disaster last week. So a string of top ministers have publicly called on her to let MPs take control of Brexit. They urged her to let Parliament vote on a range of options for what happens next.  That could lead to the question being thrown back to the British people almost three years after the  EU referendum. Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd, whose brother Roland is chairman of the Peoples Vote campaign, today declared nothing should be off the table. Every Richard Curtis film has a grumpy character called Bernard because Tory MP Bernard Jenkin stole Curtiss girlfriend at university. For example, in the classic Christmas movie Love Actually, Bernard is Emma Thompson and Alan Rickmans horrid son. For more fun facts and trivia tune in as Christmas on Dave continues tonight at :pm with a QI Christmas Special. She will back Theresa Mays deal in a vote in the Commons, but told Sky News: After that we need to find out where the will of parliament is, where the majority of MPs will vote in Parliament. And nothing should be off the table, we should consider all options.  Business Secretary Greg Clark said MPs should pass Mrs Mays Brexit deal when it eventually comes to a vote next month. But he told the BBC: If that were not to be successful, we do need to have an agreement, we cant just have continuing uncertainty. And I think Parliament should be invited to say what it would agree with. Thats something I think businesses up and down the country will expect, elected members to take responsibility rather than just be critics.  Solicitor General Robert Buckland said a free vote on the next steps might well work. He told the BBCs Westminster Hour: I thinkall the parties agreed to it then it’s something that might well work, but I think it would be imbalancedone party did it and the other did not.” International Trade Secretary Liam Fox indicated he could support MPs being given a free vote on Brexit options. He said: I wouldn’t have a huge problem with parliament as a whole having a say on what the options were, because it wasn’t the government that was given an instruction by the referendum it was parliament.  And Education Secretary Damian Hinds said: I think there is a value in, sort of, flushing out what these ious dferent options are. The Prime Minister will use an address to the Commons to say a new national poll would do irreparable damage to the integrity of British politics. It comes after close allies of Mrs May distanced themselves from reports that they were manoeuvring to bring about a fresh referendum. The PM will say: Let us not break faith with the British people by trying to stage another referendum.  Another vote which would do irreparable damage to the integrity of our politics, because it would say to millions who trusted in democracy, that our democracy does not deliver. Another vote which would likely leave us no further forward than the last. And another vote which would further ide our country at the very moment we should be working to unite it. But Labour MP Chuka Umunna said: We only formally launched Peoples Vote back in April. The fact that now, after , marched for it and over  million signed [a] petition, the PM should make this campaign the centre piece of her attack today illustrates that our campaign is working. The appearance follows Mrs Mays de facto deputy, Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington, and the PMs chief of staff, Gavin Barwell, both dismissing reports they are planning for a new referendum.  And Mrs May faces a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday following a frantic few days when key ministers have jockeyed for attention and staked out strong Brexit positions. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said Britain would prosper evenit quit the EU with no deal, while Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd argued firmly against leaving the bloc without an agreement. Prominent Brexiteers like International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt also look set to make their views known. And former foreign secretary Boris Johnson railed against the idea of a second referendum.  Writing in the Daily , he said: A second referendum would provoke instant, deep and ineradicable feelings of betrayal. Mr Johnson said the idea that the Government would hold a fresh Brexit poll was sickening. Labour is insisting that Mrs May puts her Brexit deal to a vote in the Commons before Parliament rises for Christmas on Thursday. However, the party has made it clear it will not table a motion of no confidence in the Government until such a vote has been held.

title: kevin maguire let people say
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire - Let the people have their say on BrexitMirror Associate Editor Kevin Maguire says thatTheresa May refuses another referendum, Parliament must take back control from No to let the people decideShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionTheresa May is not listening to the people, says Kevin Maguire "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFour Parliaments in post-war history were shorter than the  months wasted wrangling about how to make Britain poorer and weaker. Those -, -,  and - governments should make us question the relevance of a referendum result delivered in June  as we enter . The gravest deceit of the Right-wing Brexit elite was to mis-sell quitting Europe as easy, quick and profitable when it is anything but. Everybody is entitled to change their mind in a democracy, as former Brexit Secretary, David Davis, stated. We are clearly now better informed, with that pivotal poundmillion NHS lie nailed and prominent Leavers exposed as feuding charlatans. Obstinate Mrs May is working her notice after promising to quit No, fast becoming a bystander instead of a PM providing bold leadership.   With part of her Cabinet warming to another referendum, Parliament paralysed and others screaming for a no-deal crash, the only thing anyone agrees on is that Mrs May’s deal is dead. This column argued last month that a referendum was the way forward and it is encouraging to see Mrs May’s deputy David Lidington and chief adviser Gavin Barwell coming on board. Et tu, David  Et tu, Gavin  The knives in May’s back are Tory ones. Accusing former PM Tony Blair of insulting the nation by advocating this increasingly popular option was a boomshyshyerang jibe by Mrs May. Brexit is costing poundmillion a week, say economists, with growth and the pound down. That would soarwe ever left. Whether people knew it or not, backing Brexit was a vote to be poorer. Fighting this calamity should be a class issue for Jeremy Corbyn, as the working class will be hit hardest. May could yet embrace the democracy of a referendum butshe doesn’t, Parliament must take back control from No to let the people decide.

title: pennymordaunt plots alternative brexit vision
story: NewsPenny Mordaunt plots alternative Brexit vision with Eurosceptic Tory group in secretEXCLUSIVE: Leading cabinet Brexiteer Penny Mordaunt has been holding secret talks with key members of the hardline European Research Group in a bid to win their support for a rumoured leadership bid - and to become Prime MinisterShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsPenny Mordaunt has her eye on the top job "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLeading cabinet Brexiteer Penny Mordaunt has been plotting with key members of a eurosceptic Tory group to produce her alternative vision of Brexit. The international development secretary has been holding secret talks with key members of the hardline European Research Group in a bid to win their support for a rumoured leadership bid. She is expected to unveil detailed plans for a managed no deal to cut the UKs Brexit bill tomorrow nightin a move which will fuel speculation she wants the top job. The Mirror understands that she worked on the proposals with ERG members including Michael Tomlinson, a former deputy chair of the group who has been tipped as a future campaign manager. Ms Mordaunt, who is the only cabinet minister to fail to publicly back the PMs Brexit deal, is expected to set out more detail of her own plan to pursue a free trade agreement. Theresa May’s authority, already weakened by her ing virtually empty-handed from Brussels last week, was in shreds tonight as ministers lined up to set out their own Brexit stalls.  Remainer Amber Rudd said she should “forge a consensus” across party lines, reaching a soft Brexit consensus, while foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed the UK would “flourish and prosper” after a no deal Brexit. However, Mordaunt’s engagement with leading members of the ERG will raise eyebrows as the Brexiteer group was the force behind last week’s attempts to oust Mrs May as Tory leader. One senior Tory source said: Obviously people talk to one another but theres a pretty big leap between having a chat with Jacob [Rees-Mogg] or Steve [Baker] and working with key figures in the ERG to pull together a plan that is ultimately your plan for government. These are the people who are literally trying to get rid of her boss. Every Richard Curtis film has a grumpy character called Bernard because Tory MP Bernard Jenkin stole Curtiss girlfriend at university. For example, in the classic Christmas movie Love Actually, Bernard is Emma Thompson and Alan Rickmans horrid son. For more fun facts and trivia tune in as Christmas on Dave continues tonight at :pm with a QI Christmas Special. An ERG insider added: “Penny is the most ERG person left in the Cabinet so it’s hardly surprising that she’s fishing in the pool. Mrs May has come under growing pressure from her ministers to give MPs a free “indicative” vote on all the Brexit options this side of Christmas. They will attempt to persuade her at Cabinet tomorrow [Tuesday] that the votes would show that none of the alternatives, including a Norway-style deal or a Canada-style free trade agreement, would get majority support in parliament. The ministers have been buoyed by their success in getting the PM to cancel last week’s meaningful vote.  Education secretary Damian Hinds said it was the only way to flush out levels of parliamentary support for the dferent plans, while Trade secretary Liam Fox suggested it could break the political deadlock. Other ministers thought to back the plan include Ms Rudd, Chancellor Philip Hammond, Justice Secretary David Gauke and Business Secretary Greg Clark. Downing Street has rejected the proposal. One No  insider said: “The idea that this solves anything or is a path to anywhere is wishful thinking.” Mrs May will tomorrow hit out at calls for a new Brexit referendum after her chief of staff Gavin Barwell and de facto deputy PM David Lidington were accused of preparing for one behind her back. But the chances of a second referendum appeared to have increased in the wake of the PM’s decision to pull the vote on her deal and herfrom the EU summit without any legally binding assurances on the unpopular Irish border backstop. But she will tell MPs: “Let us not break faith with the British people by trying to stage another referendum. Another vote which would do irreparable damage to the integrity of our politics, because it would say to millions who trusted in democracy, that our democracy does not deliver. Another vote which would likely leave us no further forward than the last. And another vote which would further ide our country at the very moment we should be working to unite it.  The PM’s closest aides denied they were either planning for, or wanted, a second referendum. But both men are understood to believe that is where the country will end up. Mr Barwell tweeted: Happy to confirm I am *not* planning a nd referendum with political opponents .” Sources close to Mr Lidington also strongly denied that he had suggested to Labour MPs at a meeting last week that he was interested in pursuing the option. A wave of no deal planning is expected to be unleashed by Whitehall departments this week with preparations for a range of doomsday scenarios set into motion. Downing Street today dismissed reports that people will be advised not to book holidays after March next year according to no deal contingency plans. Home secretary Sajid Javid is also finally expected to publish the Governments immigration plans on Wednesday, with a row brewing over low-skilled workers. Meanwhile, Labour’s top team was split over the timing of holding a no confidence vote in the government. The party’s elections guru Andrew Gwynne MP said it would try to force a Brexit vote before Christmas but said Labour would not try to oust the PM until this had had taken place. But Labour’s chief whip, Nick Brown, told the BBC it was “certainly a possibility” that the party could table a no confidence vote in the Government as early as Monday. He said the fact that  of her own MPs had voted against her had given “pause for thought” on the timing of the vote. “Clearly we would have itwe had a prospect of winning,” he added. Deputy leader Tom Watson and shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer are among those backing swt action, while those backing Jeremy Corbyns more cautious approach include shadow chancellor John McDonnell and shadow education secretary Angela Rayner.

title: teachers buy pupils winter coats
story: NewsPoverty as bad as Charles Dickens era as hungry kids go without winter coats and sleep in unormEXCLUSIVE: One student wore his trousers backwards so people didnt see he had holes in knees - while many sleep in school unorm as they dont own pyjamasShareCommentsByMark Ellis:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMark Lester begs for more gruel in the  film Oliver!, based on the Dickens’ tale "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeachers are seeing shydistressing poverty among their pupils and more than half fear some will go hungry over Christmas. A poll of , teachers in England highlighted how austerity is blighting the lives of poorer families...with their shychildren bearing the brunt. One said: “Kids come in without winter coats even in the coldest weather.” Another added: “Struggling families get food packages, clothing and Christmas presents. We are starting a breakfast for every child.” Dr Mary Bousted, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, which carried out the survey, said: “This is a Dickensian picture of the poverty that far too many children and their families are having to endure.” Charles Dickens’ famous  novel Oliver Twist exposed the grinding poverty faced by many children in Victorian England. And now the spectre of want is ing to modern Britain.   Dr Bousted added: “The Government is out of touch with the new reality of children’s daily lives: with what it means to live without enough money for basics, such as food, shoes and adequate clothing. “The Government has failed to recognise the cost of cuts to schools, [to] children’s services and the social security system.” She urged “an urgent change to national policies”s and went on to blast the Tories for a “failure to address the in-work poverty faced by one in five.” More than six out  teachers said more families could not afford adequate winter clothes or shoes than three years ago. Nearly half said “holiday hunger” and housing issues, such as children living in shyovercrowded or temporary accommodation, were also worse than three years ago. And a shocking % said schools provide extra items for children and their hard-up families. One teacher said: “Good shoes are too expensive so students are coming in cheap shoes that last a few weeks at most. “I often have students asking meI can glue their shoes shyback together because the sole has fallen off.”   While one revealed that school attendance dropped to % after heavy rain “because shoes [were] damaged and many had no extra pair.” The survey said poverty was also contributing to more absences from school, behavioural issues, lack of concentration and pupils turning up late. North Denes Primary in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, have even started its own foodbank after noticing pupils were turning up hungry. Last night Angela Rayner, Labour’s Shadow Education Secretary, said: ”These figures paint a shocking picture of the impact of the Tories’ austerity on a generation of children. “Schools are being left to fend for themselves and deal with the consequences.” However the Government insisted: “Since  there are , fewer children living in absolute poverty, employment is at a record and we’re committed to ensuring every child gets the very best chances. “We spend pound billion a year on welfare to support those who need it most. On top of this, we’ve introduced funding to support disadvantaged shyfamilies in the holidays.” TIME TO END THIS MONSTROUS INJUSTICE By Louisa McGeehan, Director of Policy, Child Poverty Action Group “There is no denying the prevalence of child poverty in our schools and some teachers’ experiences are absolutely heart breaking. We know that in a class of  children, on average  are growing up in poverty. This means missing out on opportunities to fulfil their potential and enjoy childhood, it also means sometimes going hungry or missing out on trips and other activities. Schools can’t address this alone - as a compassionate nation we need to re-invest in children and tackle child poverty urgently by restoring the value of child benefit, ending the freeze on social security benefits and abolishing the  child policy that discriminates unfairly against some children. The growth in in-work poverty is a particularly worrying trend. Because of zero-hour or short-hour contracts and increasingly insecure minimum wage work, many children are growing up in poverty when at least one of their parents work. Our recent research on the cost of a child in  found that  parents with  children working full-time on the national minimum wage still can’t earn enough to meet their family’s needs even at a minimum no-frills standard. A lone parent in the same position would need to work in a job paying at least an average wage to meet the family’s needs. This growth in in-work poverty means thatfamilies earn just above the threshold, their children miss out on free school meals. “It’s not just teachers who see first hand the impact of increasing child poverty. Our work with paediatricians found that children are sick as a direct result of being poor and the impact of this is lelong. Sometimes families can’t visit sick children in hospital because they can’t afford travel costs or to miss a day of work and some children couldn’t be sent home from hospital when medically fit because the family’s housing conditions are so bad. For instance, a child needing electrical medical equipment but there is only one socket available for the fridge, cooking and everything . “ “Le is getting tougher for low-income families and poverty has an effect on all parts of a child’s le. It doesn’t have to be this way - poverty isn’t inevitable. We have tackled it before and can do this againthere is the political will to do it. Today’s children deserve no less.”

title: theresa plays only card left
story: NewsopinionTheresa May plays the only card she has left and its a joker - Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Prime Ministers ruling out of a second is a desperate move designed to deflect attention from her own failures and a ided CabinetShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionThe Prime Minister is desperate to deflect attention "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May will make yet another statement on Brexit to MPs this afternoon. After a weekend of reports that senior figures in No  and the Cabinet are exploring the option of a second referendum, the Prime Minister will insist that it is not happening . One of the more pitul aspects of Mrs May’s premiership is she has broken her word so often that when she categorically denies something the odds on it happening immediately shorten. Setting aside for the moment her nonsensical argument that additional democracy is somehow a betrayal of democracy, the Prime Minister’s rejection of a people’s vote reeks of desperation. She has been forced into this position because she needs to reassure Brexiteers that her Downing Street team is not colluding with MPs on the possibility of a second vote and she needs to deflect attention from the serious discussions under way about putting a range of Brexit options to Parliament in a bid to break the impasse and she needs cover for her own failure to wring any further concessions from the EU last week. Mrs May is also desperate to find a holding line that erts attention from the fact most of her Cabinet are plotting for a dferent Brexit while positioning for the now inevitable leadership contest. The Tory MP Sam Gyimah explained the PM’s tactics in a tweet this morning: “Downing St has stopped selling the PMs flawed deal. Instead we have displacement activity designed to distract from last weeks failed renegotiation. And a concerted attempt to discredit every plausible alternative as they run down the clock. This is not in the national interest.” In an especially clunky sentence, Mrs May will also claim another vote would “further ide our country at the very moment we should be working to unite it.” Given the polls show a majority now want a second referendum, her appeal for unity looks particularly forlorn.  You would have thought that Chris Grayling had this year’s competition to be the most disappointing Cabinet minister sewn up. Then along comes Jeremy Hunt with a late challenge in the form of his embracing of a “managed no deal Brexit.” It takes a special political gt to jump on the Leave bandwagon at the moment when most of other occupants are trying to bail out and the rest are summoning the wheelwrights before the whole charabanc completely topples over. There is also no such thing as a “managed no deal”, it is an oxymoron – and you do not have to been an expert at Scrabble to work out which word you can make from oxymoron to describe Mr Hunt. Surely he would have learnt by now from Mrs May’s experiences that there are no benefits which come from trying to ingratiate yourself with the Tory right  Even the Brexiteers are savvy enough to see through his blatant attempt to curry favour ahead of any leadership contest. And were he to win, how long do you think it would take before he realised their demands can never be satisfied  Todays agenda: .pm – Damian Hinds takes Education questions in the Commons. .pm – Theresa May statement on Brexit and last week’s EU summit. .pm – Representatives from Amazon, John Lewis and Debenhams give evidence to Housing, Communities and Local Government committee on the state of the high street. pm – Sir Philip Rutman, permanent secretary at the Home Office, is grilled by the Home Affairs select committee on the Windrush scandal. title: cheeky charming boy 6 who
story: NewsCheeky and charming boy, , who touched hearts dies weeks before ChristmasCallum Sainsbury was diagnosed with a rare form of epilepsy - Ohtahara syndrome - after suffering from  seizures a day.ShareCommentsByAnna LewisNeil Murphy:,  DEC NewsCallum with sister Kelcea "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA six-year-old boy has died two weeks before Christmas - leaving his family devastated and heartbroken. Callum Sainsbury died after a battle against a rare form of epilepsy on Tuesday. Now his family are preparing for Christmas without the cheeky and charming lad. Tributes have been pouring in for the huge rugby fan, Wales Online reported. Callum, from Brynmawr, south Wales, was diagnosed with Ohtahara syndrome as a baby after he began having up to  seizures a day. Those with the condition are particularly susceptible to repeated chest infections. His family have described how he defied the odds, and was supported by his sisters Katelyn and Kelcea. Callums mum Aime said: Callum was so cheeky, he had me wrapped around his little fingerhe wanted something, He was just so charming - theres so much to say about him. He loved rugby and he loved Jurassic World, his favourite was the raptor Blue. Throughout this year, friends and family had been raising money for Callum to have the perfect Christmas after he had spent December  in hospital for the last three years. In November, family friend Sasha Wilks also organised for the Pen-Y-Cwm pupil to meet the Wales rugby squad during their autumn campaign. Since Callums death, fundraising has now begun to support his family with the cost of his funeral.  Amie, , said: For the last five and a half weeks, Callum didnt have one fit. He went to Ty Hafan last Thursday evening and he was fine. On the night he was on oxygen and we couldnt get him off it. On the Sunday he slept all the day through and didnt wake up at all. We wanted to make him comfortable. He was in a place that was calm and they really respected our wishes. I told all the staff they could come and say their goodbyes and they did.  Since Callums death on Tuesday, his family have been overwhelmed by messages of love and support from across the UK - including from Diversity star Ashley Banjo. Aime said: We got hold of Diversity, as we had met them before, to tell them and Ashley Banjo said we were a lovely family and that he was glad he had met Callum. I cant say enough to thank people for what they have done for me and my daughters and Paul. The support has been immense. The girls are holding it together but deep down I know its bothering them really badly. They were always by his side and loved him so much.  In a video thanking friends for their support, Amie added: Our boy is really going to be missed. Callum touched everyones heart. We will never ever forget him, we will talk of him every day and we love him to bits. We are having to deal with this just before Christmas but he is safe, he is not in pain anymore, he is not suffering any more.  Its so hard to know that hes gone and he will never be there with us but he is with us - hes in our hearts. I cant thank everyone enough for what you are doing right now. Its helping us so much. title: how can served quickly bar
story: NewsHow can I get served quickly at the bar   staff secrets to avoiding queuesA former barmaid at a busy bar has revealed the best ways to get the attention of the people pulling the pintsShareCommentsByKatie Sands:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsWhos next   secrets to getting served first at the bar "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA six-deep bar queue is a heart-sinking vision of the highest order. But fear not - because there are ways of getting served ahead of the mob. Of course, you might think you already have it down. You might reckon you’re good at getting the staff’s attention  Or you may believe a cash tip is the way to go  Now, forget all that. A former employee at one of Cardfs busiest pubs told Wales Online how you can make the bar staff your new BFFs - and get served quickly as a result. And on New Years Eve, these tips might be even more important: . Don’t annoy the bar staff  Full stop. Do all you can to keep them in a happy mood. They might be paid the minimum wage to serve you drinks - but they can still make choices about who they serve first and who they serve at all. . Mind your manners This is common courtesy. We may look a little abnormal while sweating our heads off after hours behind a cramped bar, but please don’t forget we are still human. No manners equals no preferential treatment when you come back for more. . Have your wallet or purse in your hand when the staff member has finished serving your round Don’t act surprised when they ask you to pay for the booze you are about to guzzle while they have to settle for iced tap water. Get your money out, and stop time wasting. . Pay in cash If you watch closely enough, you may be able to see a barmaid die a little bit inside every time a punter pulls a Visa out of their wallet. It wastes so much valuable serving time. That said, it’s not as annoyingyou’ve made a humongous order or, say, added a drink on for said barmaid to have at the end of her sht.  We’re not allowed to accept them. We know it’s inconvenient and unhelpful, but there’s nothing we can do about it. Apologies. . Don’t wave cash in our faces to get attention  We know you’re there, even though we may avoid eye contact with all the staring faces who are mentally screaming ‘Can’t you go any faster !’ . Think about what you want to drink BEFORE it’s your turn to order  If you haven’t decided what drink you want to order by the time you move your way through a three-deep queue, then you’ve failed. We’ll move on to the decisive people before you can blink.  If you’re ft and a fag butt like me, reaching for glasses that are kept overhead is not easy. All the sympathetic drinkers who responded to my comment “If I can’t reach the glasses, you’re not getting served” and handed me clean glasses while ordering got extra kudos. Same goes for dirty glasses and punters complaining when we’ve run out. The faster we get them back, the faster we can clean them and get them back out again. . Try not to forget a drink when ordering a major round Please don’t come back to the bar five minutes later and demand one more drink. That said,you are going to do it, be polite. staff are well within their rights to tell you to queue again for being such a numpty. . Trust in the system  It may look like they haven’t got a clue who to serve next but there is usually an invisible system going on. Mine was usually to serve everyone from the Erdinger pump across to the Brains SA pump. Everyone out of that remit was on their own. . Have your own pecking order Although we do have a general idea of who’s been there a while and who’s just elbowed in, please have your own system. We can’t always swear on the Bible who was there first, andyou’re too busy bickering with the guy who may or may not have cut in front of you, we’ll move on. . Try not to get annoyed at family members of bar staff who get preferential treatment We know it’s hard, but you’d expect special treatmentyou were in their position too . If you’re going to delve into the minefield of small talk, make it worth our while Jokes  Great. Who do I think is going to win  Yes, that makes me feel like my limited rugby knowledge is valued. Why did the chicken cross the road  Just stop right there. How to stop nuisance calls and text messages . Don’t you dare have the audacity to complain about how long you’ve been waiting for a drink Technically, the ones behind the bar are the ones who’ve been waiting the longest for a drink. So zip it. If anyone has the right to complain about how hot it is, how loud it is, how claustrophobic it is because there are about a million people between you and the exit, it’s definitely not you. . title: how heroic chester zoo staff
story: NewsHow heroic Chester Zoo staff saved terried orangutans from devastating fireChester Zoo employees have been praised by bosses for their efforts during the blaze which has been described as one of the "toughest days in its long history"ShareCommentsBySteve BagnallZara WhelanMarc Waddington-NWAmber Hicks:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video chester-zoo-press-conference-bosses-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChester Zoo staff were able to save all the orangutans from the devastating fire by coaxing the terried animals out of the burning building. Employees encouraged them to safety by calling them and using the strong bonds they had developed with the apes. Once all of the orangutans had been accounted for, staff ensured the door back inside was closed.The animals then wrapped themselves in blankets as a comfort mechanism. Today, devastated staff confirmed all animals who survived are fine and attempts are being made to give them one-to-one health checks.Zoo bosses have also hailed the heroic staff after the fire broke out just before Saturday lunchtime in the Monsoon Forest complex. It quickly engulfed the building, with the whole park evacuated shortly afterwards, reports North Wales Live.   The dome-roofed centre is home to thousands of animals, including primates, crocodiles, snakes and fish. As the inferno raged, zoo staff went into the burning rainforest and brought the creatures - some of which are critically endangered - out to safety. At a press conference, the zoos animal and plant director Mike Jordan said while the larger animals had been rescued, some of the other species - including birds and fish - had died. He said: We know some animals have died. The house contained everything from spiders to stick insects, fish, frogs - it was an incredibly complex forest environment. “Where the fire broke out, we know it was in the vicinity of some fish and insects, and that area has been completely destroyed by fire.   We cannot confirm the exact numbers [of animals that have died] and in some cases it will be uncertain numbers of very small animals. “A very small number of bird carcasses have been recovered but most of the others recovered are alive and healthy. “We lost none of the mammals, none of the primates. We lost none of the gibbons, none of the macaques, none of the orangutans. All of these as of today are safe and being looked after. We were able with our keepers and the relationships they have with the animals, the strong bond between them, to call the animals out. “It allowed us to lead the animals out into their outdoor area and with the help of the fire brigade we were able to get into the enclosure and close the hatches to lock them outside. So eventhey were a little bit chilly at least they were safe.   “Lots of the orangutans have sacking or blankets they like to cuddle and carry around with them. Any that did that during the evacuation, it was self controlled. We didn’t wrap them up in blankets, they did it themselves. I think it was a comfort issue.” At the height of the blaze there were  fire engines tackling it, and high winds from Storm Deirdre sent into the air a large plume of smoke that could be seen for miles around.Eyewitnesses described seeing animals that had been in the building when it went up attempting to make their escape. Antony Johnstone, who was visiting the zoo with his we, daughter and two friends, described seeing orangutans and gibbons leaving the building.   He said: “We were about to literally step foot into the building when another visiting family, who were stood in the entrance, said there was a fire starting and it was closed. “As we walked around the side of the building on the footpath, we could see all the animals were released outside the fire had spread and lots of black smoke came out of the building. “We walked to another area of the zoo and then were told the zoo was closing. “The staff reacted very well and moved the public away, the zoo also issued refunds to our friends with no problems. “We are members of the zoo and it was such a shame to see this happening.” Antony said he saw staff letting the animals into the outside part of their enclosure. He added: “We saw the orangutans coming out and the gibbons swinging around the netting on the enclosure.” By mid-afternoon, the Monsoon Forest had lost its entire polymer roof. Photographs released by Cheshire Fire and Rescue Service revealed the dense, lush rainforest enclosure was now a bare, charred, ash-filled shell.   The Islands complex only opened in , and cost around poundm. By late afternoon on Sunday a fundraising campaign had seen more than pound, donated towards rebuilding the habitat. The zoo was open as normal on Sunday and its popular Christmas lantern parade was set to go ahead as normal. But zoo bosses said it had one of the toughest days in our long history. Chief operating officer Jamie Christon added: The remarkable efforts from the zoo team and the emergency services meant the fire was extinguished as quickly as possible. Visitors were evacuated immediately and we would like to thank them for their understanding and cooperation. Thankfully, no staff or public were harmed in the incident. Keepers were able to encourage all mammal species away from the fire and to safety - including the zoo’s group of critically endangered Sumatran orangutans, Sulawesi macaques, endangered silvery gibbons and birds such as rhinoceros hornbills.   We are though, devastated to say that we were unable to save some of our insects, frogs, fish and small birds who were located near to the outbreak of the fire.It’s absolutely heartbreaking to lose any animal, especially when conservationists have worked so hard to breed these wonderful species. New homes have been found within the zoo for all of the animals that were led to safety and our teams are working around the clock to relocate them as soon as possible. The strength and support from the public has been incredibly overwhelming and the messages of goodwill have been of great comfort to our teams. We will support each other in rebuilding this part of the zoo and continue our mission of preventing extinction. The cause of the fire is currently unknown, but we will be helping the relevant authorities with the investigation that will take place over the coming days and weeks. We would again, like to thank the emergency services for their swt response. One person was treated for smoke inhalation at the scene, but there were no reports of any other injuries. An investigation into how the fire started is ongoing, Cheshire Fire and Rescue Service said.

title: uproar hotel cancels charitys christmas
story: NewsHotel cancels Christmas booking for  homeless people sparking uproarCarl Simpson fears his ambition to give nearly  rough sleepers a safe place to stay is now in jeopardy, after the Royal Hotel allegedly cancelled his £, bookingShareByAlex GroveLuke Kenton:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsCarl Simpsons intiative to get nearly  homeless people off the streets for Christmas has been put in jeopardy, he says "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA charity has criticised a hotel after it allegedly cancelled a booking which would have given  homeless people a safe place to sleep for Christmas. Coming as part of the Raise the Roof Homeless project, Carl Simpson paid pound, for  twin rooms at the Britannia Royal Hotel, inHull, for Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. The fundraiser says he informed the hotel of the bookings details and who would be staying in the rooms over the two nights, but he was left shocked when he received a call on Saturday where he was allegedly told the booking had been cancelled. The hotel has said no one is available to comment on the matter.   Mr Simpson, , took to the charity’s Facebook page to upload images of receipts and invoices from the hotel and emails confirming the booking. He said he was “absolutely gutted” by the decision and said his goal to get Hulls rough sleepers off the streets for Christmas is now in jeopardy. Mr Simpson said: “We approached the Royal Hotel and told them exactly what we were doing. They were quite happy with it and even got us a  per cent discount. “They knew homeless people were coming to the hotel and I even went in and paid by card but then yesterday out of the blue I got a phone call to say that they had cancelled the booking and that they would refund us. “I asked them what the reason was and they said that they weren’t sure and that they would get back to us. The phone went on hold and then they said they couldn’t tell me – they didn’t seem bothered at all.” The pound,, which has been amassed with the help of generous members of the public, will now be paid back to Mr Simpson but he says it could take a few days for the money to be ed. Last year, Mr Simpson was able to get  rough sleepers inside the Ibis hotel in Ferensway for December  and , and he was keen to repeat the feat this year.   However, with Christmas Eve just a week away, he is now worried that he will not be able to fulfil his ambition. “We got the receipt for it so on Thursday at our soup kitchen we told them all that they were sorted for Christmas,” Mr Simpson said. “They were over the moon and we wanted to tell them that to give them something to look forward to instead of dreading Christmas like they usually do by reflecting on what they’ve lost. “Now, we are going to have to break this news to them and it’s heartbreaking. “Having somewhere to sleep at Christmas can be the dference between le and death. Christmas is the lowest time of the year and suicide in the homeless section is higher than any other time of year. “It gives them safety and a chance to get in a bed which for some is something they haven’t been able to do in years. “These people don’t have a great deal to look forward to but this would have given them a little bit of a lt so to have it taken away from them at the last minute is devastating for them.”  Mr Simpson wants other hotels to help his charitythey can. He said: “We are not surewe will get anywhere  because everywhere is booked up and the longer we wait the more expensive the rooms get. “If the Royal Hotel could rethink what they are doing oranyone  could come forward then at the end of the day they could be saving a le.” Britannia Hotels, which runs the Ferensway hotel, has been contacted for a comment by Hull Live in relation to the cancellation.

title: mum who left two toddlers
story: NewsToddlers suffered painful, slow death in hot car after mum abandoned themWhen someone heard the girls crying and asked mother Amanda Kristene Hawkinsthey should be brought inside, she responded "No, theyll cry themselves to sleep," it is reportedShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsAmanda Hawkins was mum to Addyson and Brynn "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who left her two toddlers to die in a hot car while she partied and smoked marijuana has been jailed for  years. Amanda Hawkins, , left toddlers Addyson Overgard-Eddy, two, and Brynn Hawkins, one, inside the sweltering car for  hours without food or water. Ignoring their cries for help, she spent the night at a friends house in Kerr County, Texas. When someone heard the girls crying and asked Hawkinsthey should be brought inside, she responded No, theyll cry themselves to sleep, according to reports. By the time she went back to the car to get her children the following afternoon on June , , they had collapsed unconscious in C heat.  But instead of taking them to hospital straight away, the mum gave them a bath and dressed them in a dferent set of clothes. They were eventually taken to hospital on June  but tragically died on June  last year, according to Fox . In September, Hawkins pleaded guilty to two counts of reckless injury to a child and two counts of abandoning or endangering a child.  She initially tried to cover up her neglect by telling doctors they passed out after smelling flowers at a local park. Witnesses testied that shed said theyd become stumbly and red after snfing the flowers. But it was later found that the mum had left her girls in a vehicle while she smoked marijuana in a shed.  A judge handed Hawkins four  year sentences, with two sets of them running concurrently. Hill County Breaking News reports that before sentencing, Hawkins made a statement saying: “I will accept whatever the punishment may be,” and that “there are no excuses for what I did.” Kerr County Sherf Hierholzer previously said in a statement: “This is by far the most horric case of child endangerment that I have seen in the  years that I have been in law enforcement.  Kevin Franke,  at the time, slept in the car with the girls because he didnt want to sleep in the shed, but said he was unaware they were there, the Daily Mail reports. The now--year-old pleaded not guilty in April to two counts of manslaughter, two counts of injury to a child and two counts of child endangerment. He will go on trial in January.

story: NewsUnemployed man earns £, a month to fund lestyle by begging onlineJovan Hill, , from Brooklyn, films himself asking his social media followers for cash so he can pay his rent among other expensesShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video jovan-hill-pays-new-york-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn unemployed college drop-out has revealed how he earns pound, a month by begging online so he can fund his lestyle. Jovan Hill films himself asking his social media followers to donate cash so he can pay his rent and living expenses, which includes buying video games, vintage t-shirts and cannabis. The -year-old, who lives in Brooklyn, uses social media s such as Periscope, Instagram, YouTube and Twitter to ask for cash from his , plus followers.In one video he is filmed saying: “I’m very poor today.“Soyou want any tax write-offs, please donate to the Jovan charity.”   And amazingly his pleas work. Within minutes of posting his videos, donations begin to flood in to his PayPal account from loyal fans. One wrote: The only reason I wake up and go to work everyday is so I can give @EHJovan money for rent. Jovan, who uses his iPhone to rant about anything and everything, says he is amazed that random people send him money.“When I talk to friends who have known me for a long time, they could never understand sending a random person money, and I kind of feel the same way,” he told the New York Times. “But it’s a community. A community based around me.” He first encountered the generosity of online strangers when in  he asked for help because his grandmothers power had been turned off because of unpaid bills. Followers sent him ,.   “That was the first time I realised my followers care about my well-being, he said. Jovan, who grew up in Texas with  siblings and was raised by a single mother who was a Jehovah’s Witness, moved to New York to start over when he dropped out of college following a bad breakup. With pittance in his pocket he knew he needed to get a job and started working at a cinema.But shortly afterwards he quit and thats when he began making his regularly social media call-outs for cash. Jovan, who says he is bipolar and a manic depressive, describes his videos as a gay, broke diary. Viewers occasionally ask him why he doesn’t get a traditional job, to which he replies: “I made this my job.”

title: france ready use last resort
story: NewsFrance ready to use last-resort chemical weapon against rioting Yellow VestsAstonishing revelations about the debilitating powder highlights the increasing desperation of President Emmanuel Macrons administration in France - after five straight weeks of violence by Yellow Vests protestersShareCommentsByPeter Allen:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsProtesters wearing yellow vests clash with riot police during a demonstration on the Champs-Elysees in Paris "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrench security forces are ready to smother the centre of Paris with a last resort chemical weapon in a bid to keep rioters away from key buildings, it has emerged. Astonishing revelations about the debilitating powder – which can be spread across an area the size of six football pitches in just  seconds – highlights the increasing desperation of President Emmanuel Macrons administration as it faces up to a law and order crisis. Paris has been hit by five straight weeks of violence by the Yellow Vests protest movement that has seen national monuments including the Arc de Triomphe ransacked. There were  arrests in the city on Saturday alone as the demonstrators – who are named after their high visibility jackets – fought running battles with police, who responded with water cannon, baton charges and teargas.  Now senior officers have confirmed that some of the  armoured cars deployed by gendarmes contained a radical device that was only to be used as a last resort against their own citizens. A gun-like distributor on the vehicles turrets can spray the powder over , square meters in  seconds, Marianne magazine reports. The high-density noxious product contains the same power as  teargas grenades, and is designed to knock people out indiscriminately in an emergency. If a large crowd forced barriers through the security perimeter, then the powder would be used as a last resort in order to stop them, said a source at the Paris police prefecture.  But it is sure to raise concerned questions among civic rights groups, as well as monitoring organisations, including the Hague-based Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, of which France is a member. Colonel Richard Carminache, of the Gendarmerie, confirmed that the controversial devices had never been used in cities to my knowledge. Each distribution would result in a highly concentrated teargas cloud, the equivalent of  grenades in one go, said Col. Carminache, who added: It’s best to run to get out.  Teargas is classed as a chemical weapon, and is actually banned from warzones, in line with international agreements. Yet French gendarmes and police – who have been criticised during the latest law and order crisis for acts of extreme violence against civilians – use it constantly. In Britain, teargas use is heavily restricted, and never used indiscriminately against large crowds containing men, women and children, as happens in France.

title: mums ingenious 2 cleaning trick
story: NewsMums ingenious £ cleaning trick that has transformed her stained furnitureThe woman from Queensland, Australia, revealed her method on Facebook group Mums Who Clean, sharing photos of a sofa that now looks unrecognisableShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe mum has shared before and after pictures of her furniture "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has shared an ingenious cleaning trick that has completely transformed her stained sofa - and it only costs pound. The mother, from Queensland in Australia, uses denture cleaner Polident in her living room. She bought the bottle and tested it on her dirty couch and old looking floor tiles, and they have ended up looking as good as new. Incredible pictures show the amazing transformation - before and after the clever trick.The woman explained on Facebook group Mums Who Clean how she went about the task.I used the warm water and put three tablets in, waited for it to dissolve and then sprayed it on the sofa, she told.  She then let the solution set for about five minutes before scrubbing the chairs hard with a brush, and used a towel to soak in the filthy water.This method was repeated until she found no dirt on the towel.According to the Daily Mail, the mum added: Because Im living in a unit I just turned on the air conditioning and a fan to dry the couch.It has come out great. Our sofa is about five or six years old and this is the first time weve cleaned it.   To get the results she wanted, she needed three bottles of water and nine Polident tablets. And other mums love the technique.Some said theyd used Polident before and agreed it had worked for them.

title: 500k needed for upgrade work at dundee crematorium
story: The Dundee Crematorium will have to raise £, in order to install a new cremator that accommodates larger coffins. vw, px"  Dignity, who operate the premises, are looking at better ways to carry out services, with the current set up meaning bigger coffins have to be transferred  miles to Friockheim, with the permission of the families involved.The crematorium can only take coffins with a maximum width of  inches, but the improvement works could increase that to  inches.To carry out the project, bosses at the Macalpine Road premises have revealed it will take a six- figure sum.A spokesman said: “Like many of the oldest crematoria in the UK, the mechanism for transporting the coffin to the cremator was designed to replicate burial at a time before cremation became commonplace.“The coffin is lowered from the chapel through a brick aperture to the cremator in the room below .“It restricts the coffins we can accept to a maximum width of  inches.“On occasions when the coffin exceeds these dimensions, families will choose to have the service at Dundee.“With their permission, the coffin is cremated at another crematorium and the ashes ed to the family.”He added: “Once we have completed the current refurbishment of the chapel we will begin to plan for installing a new cremator.“It would be able to accept coffins up to  inches wide.“This will be a complex project as Dundee Crematorium is a listed building. It will require an additional investment of £,.“We plan to have the new cremator in place within the next  months.“While the size of coffins has increased over the last  years it’s only recently that advances in technology have made it possible to install cremators such as this at Dundee.”The latest proposals come just months after it was revealed the crematorium would be investing £, in the upkeep of the building.A temporary chapel has been erected at the centre in order for the building to remain open during the process. As well as installing new lighting fixtures inside the chapel, a video tribute facility is also part of the six-figure refurbishment.The current works are expected to be finished by the end of the year.Built in , the Dundee Crematorium is one of the oldest in Scotland.Paul Craigie, , of Affertons Funeral Care on Clepington Road has welcomed the latest upgrade plans.He said: “I’ve been in this profession for more than  years and it does happen from time to time that we need to go to Frockheim.“I wasn’t aware of these plans.“It’s only a good thing for local families that these improvements are being made.”
